Posts.Content: May 5, 2011 07:05AM Letlet wrote: Ladies today was #25/25, yes no more rads and never please God ever again. Between Monday and last night, the blisters popped open and my skin started coming off! It's really gross, scary to look at, I try not to touch it because it just keeps coming off. They gave me silvadene creme to put on the open blisters yesterday. I asked my husband to help me rinse/clean my armpit before putting it on. I didn't realize how much it would hurt. When he poured the sterile water on the open blister I screamed and I think that startled both of us. After he put the silvadene on my armpit I asked him to slather me with aquaphor. He went over it ever so gently and when it came to other redder parts that look like they might form into blisters, I started trembling from the pain. I'm crying silently, I look over to my husband and I see that he is crying silently too and trying to get a grip on it. We were praying the other night and in the middle of our prayer he suddenly says "Lord please give it to me instead!". I was like NO, NO, NO....  As I come home my bottle of Tamoxifen was waiting for me at the door. I'm terrified of taking it but I just said a quick prayer...see you at the other end after 5 years ...and took it.  Big cyber hug to everyone :)))

Posts.Content: May 15, 2013 08:53PM Letlet wrote: How is it that she had a "boob job"? The last time I checked a prophylactic mastectomy was still a mastectomy. She had all her breast tissue removed from both her breasts and more information released today states she had implants with alloderm to keep it in place. She probably has no sensation across her chest as most women who have had a MX experience. I had a mastectomy too and have a silicone implant - I did not have a "boob job". When she refers to her scars, it also relates as to how her children see her. Every now and then I jokingly refer to my chest as Frankenboob - it pisses the hell out of my husband but to my kids (8 and 4) its "Mommy" and I'm sure her kids see her that way too. She's just telling her story. She doesn't have to breakdown in her article the different types of mastectomies or plan A or B or C or if you are a lady in XYZ situation you can do this, this, this. This is her situation, her story. She is not speaking for other women. She can't talk about huge scars that she incurred because I doubt she had an ALND and I doubt that she had a dIEP. I don't think she was minimizing people's experiences but just telling her story. I endured hellish chemo, radiation burns and the loss of my breast. If someone told me 5 years ago that I had an 87% chance of getting BC and there was a way for me NOT to get it and NOT to go through hell on earth I would probably do the same. She watched her mom die of ovarian cancer as well. I don't think this is a decision she chose lightly.  She made a career on making movies, can you imagine acting out a lovescene? My eyes would have to be open to know that my boob is being touched I don't know how she'll manage.

Posts.Content: Oct 29, 2010 04:46PM Letlet wrote: Hi Suzela, I just wanted to respond to your post and let you know that your worry might be moot at this point. I was scheduled to get my first dose of AC yesterday and I was surprised to be informed that there is a nationwide shortage of Adrimycin and starting Monday10/25/10 my hospital was substituting Epirubicin in its place temporarily until the manufacturer Bedford (?) makes more. They said there is a high demand for the A (so sad) So for my first chemo yesterday I got EC instead of AC. My med onc assured me that they are both anthracyclines and that there is less cardiotoxicity involved and that this was the standard treatment for the women in Europe. I was amazed at how calmly I took this news, all set to get AC and got EC and found out on the day...I guess God just held my hand and prevented a major melt-down...after all those weeks of preparing for AC, research and everything, I got somethine else instead. Anyway, I just shrugged my shoulders and said..let's do it.  You know what, I think one of the nurses said that the supply might come in on November-ish so I would ask the hospital where she is being treated if they have that shortage too.  Hope this post helps.

Hi Cathy, well it's good that you think yours is most likely benign. I would think that the radiologist is recommending the biopsy for some reason. I am 100% Asian with absolutely no family history, not a smoker but since my diagnosis, I enjoy a glass or two of a nice drink, I had none of those risk factors. My breasts were dense because I was 31 at that time. Since that time BC does not care who you are, what your habits are - there is no rhyme or reason. Anyway yeah, I had a huge tumor that I never noticed, never felt any lumps and got dx with BC. The best "side-effect" that I've had throughout this is being alive.

I am supposed to be on my good week and I'm tired, I have no energy...I am 31 years old, this is not how its supposed to work :(  I guess I'm afraid now because I will have chemo on Friday...if I am this tired now, how will I be on my "bad" days next week??? Posts.Title: Anyone on or been on ECT chemo treatments mamaoftwo Letlet

Posts.Content: Jan 31, 2011 12:52PM Letlet wrote: Hi Laura, my first dose of EC really knocked me out for a loop. Most women on these boards say that generally the first tx is somewhat the worst because you don't know what to expect from how your body will react. My oncologist gave me 2 anti-nausea meds and they didn't work for me the first time. Bear in mind that everyone is different and that a lot of women go through chemo and work. I was not able to. I got really nauseous when I got home from the infusion, couldn't hold anything down. Ate crackers, small bland things. Also I have acid reflux which made me throw up. I had to go to my oncologist to get fluids later. Anyway my schedule would be EC on Thursday, feel okay Friday, feel okay saturday. On sunday night I would start getting tired. Then from Monday - Wed, Thursday I would be extremely fatigued. Extremely. The period of fatigue would actually get longer as my treatments progressed. My nausea improved so much that by my 3rd EC tx I didn't have to take any anti-nausea meds and was eating fine. When I switched over to Taxol, I had absolutely no nausea at all. I had a bit more of energy than with the EC, the fatigue was nowhere as bad as the EC. I had a lot of bone pain when I got the first Taxol and the pain meds barely helped. My onc gave me some steroids for the bone pain and the difference was night and day. I grew some peach fuzz in my armpit! My eyebrows and lashes thinned and I'm still hoping that they stay. The tips of my fingers and toes are numb. Some ladies take some supplement for it and said that it helps but my onc refuses to have me on any supplement except Vit D. In the middle of my tx my skin grew darker and I got some brown spots on the bottom of my feet and fingers and my nails turned darker. I also had digestive issues all throughout, seesawing between constipation and diarrhea. Anyway, PLEASE don't let this scare of discourage you. This is MY experience. You may not even experience any one of those SE above and if you do at least you wont be up at night googling things like I did (for the brown spots) . After my first tx, the last tx seemed so far away , that it would never come but now I'll have my last Taxol on Thursday. Chemo will be over for you too!

Posts.Title: How do you get a specialist to take you seriously? FlyingSolo FlyingSolo

Posts.Content: Dec 10, 2010 03:52PM - edited Aug 20, 2013 05:22AM by Letlet Hey Ling, It looks like your path report is leaning towards inflammatory breast cancer (IBC). IBC is a rare for of BC and aggressive. So with that in mind you want to fight this as as hard as you can, as soon as possible. With that being said, you also want to get your treatments, surgery right the first time around. It concerns me that your first chemo class is after your chemo? You need to be informed what drug you'll be on, what side effects, what your schedule is. Also your oncologist needs to go over your hormone receptors, you'll find them posted on other members signature. If you are ER (estrogen)  positive or negative, PR (progesterone) positive and HER2 negative or positive. Those 3 things will influence your treatments down the road as well. Her2 positive patient's will receive a drug called Herceptin which is touted to cut down the rates of recurrence by 50%. I would actually suggest posting your situation and if you would want to share your path report again to the IBC thread that we have. The ladies there are more qualified than I am to give advice about it. I have IDC so it's not quite the same. If the difference of you starting chemo and getting a second opinion is a day, it might be a good idea to go get that second opinion. It may change your outlook and game plan for the disease completely or it may not. It might make a difference if you tell the nurse secretary that your path leans towards IBC. I work in a cancer hospital and when someone presents with IBC we make sure to get up from our chairs and help the lady asap. Doctors will make adjustments to their schedules because it is so rare. Also remember that the Stamford may likely look at your initial path from your first biopsy and reread it as well and it may shed more light and more detail, just because their pathologists are especially trained to look for cancer. This is NOT to frighten you but to empower you with information and let you know that you have choices and although you cannot control what is happening to you right now, you can control your choices. Whatever you decide we are still here with you to support you.

Posts.Content: Dec 10, 2010 08:49AM Letlet wrote: Ling, I do undertand time is of the essence . From what I understand that the the path from your multiple biopsies have been complicated but you are scheduled for treatment at a local hospital on Monday. Some Cancer centers may or may not see you when you have already begun treatment. I work in a cancer center that does not see patients for a second opinion if treatment was already begun. If and hopefully it wont be, IBC which is a rare caner, you really want to be seen at a specialized cancer center and be treated by docs who see these cases much more than the local doctor. Did your doctor tell you if the path showed invasive ducal cancer (IDC) or invasive lobular cancer (ILC)? Did he discuss why you are having chemo first before surgery, it is because they want to shrink it first before surgery? Do you know what chemo regimen you will be on and did they go over the side effects with you? Will you be needing an injection the day after? I don't mean to overwhelm you with questions but is there someone with you when you go to your appointments. Sometimes because everything is just a shock, we hear only what we can hear and the rest tuned out. This is just my own opinion, I mean your local hospital may be wonderful anyway in dealing with your situation and the decision is all up to you. Posts.Content: Feb 21, 2011 05:05PM Letlet wrote: During my core biopsy I had a couple of injecions around the suspicious area so I was completely numbed up for the procedure. I felt the needle going in but I was not in pain. I felt sore the next two days and that was it. Some women feel a lot of pain the next day and some don't. I myself feel like I have a somewhat lower pain threshold than other women. I think I may have taken Tylenol the next day. About the marker/clip, it's left there so that in the event that your results come out positive then the surgeon knows where to take out the tissue. I have never heard of a woman refusing it but then again I was too shell shocked to even think at that point. So based on that woman who refused the marker, why would you have another core biopsy if you already had one and it already was positive? Trust me if the results were positive you would want to go to the next step as soon as possible and having another core biopsy may seem ridiculous to you at that point. Also in the event that it is positive and you don't have that marker, you don't want the surgeon to take out the wrong spot. All this would be moot if a mastectomy is chosen because everything is taken out including the clip. I have not heard any stories about chest wall perforation. In my experience the needle which was big did not go directly in the breast pointed towards my chest. The radiologist used the ultrasound wand around my breast and when he found the suspicious area he angled the needle sideways and took the sample. Why don't you discuss the issue with the radiologist before the procedure? Ask him how many core biopsies he/she has done and if there was anybody who had a perforation.

Posts.Content: Jan 21, 2011 06:56AM Letlet wrote: Hi Anette. I am not an expert on LE but I go to see an LE therapist and she told me that the number of nodes taken out does not really determine LE. She said that she has seen patients who just had a biopsy of their LN who develop LE. Second of all, the symptoms in your arm is really concerning. I am surprised that your onc does not seem to be on top of it? From what you are describing I am hoping it is not extravasation, which is when chemo goes directly into the tissues of the arm not into the bloodstream. It happens when the needle goes out of the vein into the arm tissues. It causespain, reddening and can be very serious. I would call you med onc again and ask him/her to evaluate your arm asap.

It is there all the time and it rubs on my clothes, even rubs on myself. Has anyone had this and it went away? I closed my eyes and asked my hubby to touch all over and of course there was silence as I'm waiting and waiting. I was in tears, of course I didn't feel anything, I walked into surgery knowing this but now my left arm just "feels" everything??? There is no happy medium. Sorry now I'm just plain angry.
